Description: Ceramic lamp of Greek style. Wheel-made, with threadmarks under base. Some traces of burning at nozzle. Unslipped, with a slightly rough surface and well-fired. Brown Nile silt, (Munsell 5YR6/4-5) with lime inclusions and some very small mica.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by McLean Museum and Art Gallery, Greenock. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Appears to be an Egyptian copy of an Athenian lamp. A parallel from Egypt dated to the early Ptolemaic period is in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q524). The Athenian type that was copied, has an example in the British Museum dated 305BC to 295BC (Bailey 1975, Lamp I, Q86, GR1866,0101.315). Late 4th or 3rd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Blondé 1998, 319-20, no. 14). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée D’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.48) (Phase 1)
